me.elrod.pureio

Class ConsoleFileCoproduct<A>

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.elrod.pureio.ConsoleFileCoproduct<A>

  • public class ConsoleFileCoproduct<A>
extends java.lang.Object
    Here we demonstrate how you might use the concept of a coproduct to combine grammars of various types of I/O. In this particular case, we build up a coproduct over TerminalOperation and FileOperation. Using coproducts causes the trampolining technique to no longer work (and it would be nice to find a solution to this in the future), so we don't make use of TerminalOperationT here. This structure makes use of Either and is very similar to Either<TerminalOperation, FileOperation> except that we write some useful instances over it. That is, A => F[A] \/ G[A] is a functor, given functors F and G. We can then construct a free monad over this to combine both grammars. In reality, coproducts, of course, generalize to any two functors (or foldables or traversables, or comonads). But in Java, we are only able to write one very specific instance of this construct.

    • Method Detail

      • left

        public static <A> ConsoleFileCoproduct<A> left(TerminalOperation<A> p)
        Lift a TerminalOperation.
        left :: f a -> Coproduct f g a
        left = Coproduct . Left

      • right

        public static <A> ConsoleFileCoproduct<A> right(FileOperation<A> f)
        Lift a FileOperation.
        right :: g a -> Coproduct f g a
        right = Coproduct . Right

      • cata

        public <X> X cata(java.util.function.Function<TerminalOperation<A>,X> p,
                  java.util.function.Function<FileOperation<A>,X> f)
        Catamorphism over the coproduct.
        coproduct :: (f a -> b) -> (g a -> b) -> Coproduct f g a -> b
        coproduct f g = either f g . getCoproduct

      • map

        public <B> ConsoleFileCoproduct<B> map(java.util.function.Function<A,B> f)
        Functor map over the coproduct.
        instance (Functor f, Functor g) => Functor (Coproduct f g) where fmap f = Coproduct . coproduct (Left . fmap f) (Right . fmap f)

        Lift an instance of the coproduct into a monad context.
